title: Introduction to Modeling in Epidemiology
summary: This chapter introduces the role of models in plant disease epidemiology, emphasizing their use in simplifying complex biological data to understand, predict, compare, and communicate epidemic processes, with a focus on disease intensity over time and space.
relationships: disease intensity increases over time (disease progress curve)
disease intensity decreases with distance from inoculum source (disease gradient)
yield loss correlates with mean disease intensity
id: Introduction to Modeling in Epidemiology

title: Scalable Early Detection of Plant-Pathogen Interactions With Airborne Imaging Spectroscopy: A Remote Sensing Approach
summary: This dissertation demonstrates the feasibility of using airborne imaging spectroscopy (e.g., AVIRIS-NG) for early detection of asymptomatic Grapevine Leafroll-associated Virus 3 (GLRaV-3) infections in vineyards, and explores spectral differentiation of grape varietals with cloud-native machine learning workflows for scalable disease monitoring.
relationships: Spectral reflectance changes correlate with asymptomatic GLRaV-3 infection
Imaging spectroscopy data can distinguish between red and white grape varietals
Machine learning models link physiological plant responses to spectral traits for disease prediction
Spatial, temporal, and ecological contexts influence model accuracy for disease detection
id: Scalable Early Detection of Plant-Pathogen Interactions With Airborne Imaging Spectroscopy: A Remote Sensing Approach

title: Spatial Aspects of Epidemics—II: A Theory of Spatio-Temporal Disease Dynamics
summary: This chapter develops mechanistic models for spatio-temporal dynamics of plant disease epidemics, using potato late blight and wheat stripe rust as examples to illustrate large-scale and small-scale spread, respectively. It expands on previous temporal and spatial models to understand disease expansion and control strategies.
relationships: Disease intensity increases with time and expands in space due to dispersal of infectious units
Rate of expansion is influenced by pathogen dispersal mechanisms and environmental factors
Yield loss is correlated with disease intensity and spread rate
Disease foci expand radially from infection points due to spore production and dispersal
Large-scale spread (e.g., potato late blight) occurs wave-like across regions, while small-scale spread (e.g., wheat stripe rust) involves focal expansion in fields
id: Spatial Aspects of Epidemics—II: A Theory of Spatio-Temporal Disease Dynamics

title: Climate Change Effects on Pathogen Emergence: Artificial Intelligence to Translate Big Data for Mitigation
summary: The paper reviews how artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning can integrate big data, including climate and remote sensing data, to improve predictive models for plant disease management under climate change, enabling better decision support from farm to global levels.
relationships: Climate change shifts weather patterns, increasing plant disease risk and pathogen invasion potential
Temperature and moisture availability directly influence plant disease risk
AI and machine learning integrate big data (e.g., climate, remote sensing) to improve predictive models for disease management
Decision support systems use AI to provide alerts and target responses based on risk analysis
id: Climate Change Effects on Pathogen Emergence: Artificial Intelligence to Translate Big Data for Mitigation

title: Temporal Analysis I: Quantifying and Comparing Epidemics
summary: This chapter discusses the characterization of plant disease epidemics through disease progress curves (DPCs), emphasizing the importance of modeling disease intensity over time to understand host-pathogen-environment interactions, compare treatments, and evaluate control strategies.
key_variables: area under the disease progress curve (AUDPC)
relationships: Disease intensity (y) changes over time (t) forming a disease progress curve (DPC)
Host, pathogen, and environmental factors interact to influence disease development
Control strategies and treatments affect the rate of disease change and final intensity
AUDPC summarizes overall epidemic severity and allows comparison between treatments
Repeated-measures ANOVA or AUDPC analysis can determine treatment effects on disease progression
id: Temporal Analysis I: Quantifying and Comparing Epidemics

title: Divergent abiotic spectral pathways unravel pathogen stress signals across species
summary: The study demonstrates that hyperspectral and thermal imaging can distinguish biotic stress from pathogens like Xylella fastidiosa and Verticillium dahliae from abiotic stress (e.g., water stress) with high accuracy (>92%) by identifying pathogen- and host-specific spectral pathways, enabling early detection of infections before visible symptoms appear.
relationships: Pathogen infection causes alterations in stomatal regulation, chlorophyll fluorescence, photosynthesis, and transpiration
These physiological changes produce unique spectral signatures detectable via hyperspectral and thermal imaging
Spectral pathways are divergent between biotic (pathogen-induced) and abiotic (e.g., water) stresses
Pathogen-specific spectral fingerprints enable accurate early detection (>92% accuracy) across different hosts and pathosystems
id: Divergent abiotic spectral pathways unravel pathogen stress signals across species

title: Emerging Themes and Approaches in Plant Virus Epidemiology
summary: This review identifies recent emerging themes and approaches in plant virus epidemiology, focusing on the impact of climatic fluctuations and change on host-virus-vector interactions, host resistance and tolerance, disease management strategies, computational techniques for parameter estimation, and optimal control analysis for disease control.
relationships: host-virus-vector-environment interaction affects disease dynamics
climatic fluctuations disproportionately impact plant, virus, and vector components
host resistance and tolerance influence disease development and management
farmer behavior affects deployment of disease control measures
spatial and temporal factors contribute to disease progress in field populations
computational techniques estimate epidemiological parameters from field data
optimal control analysis assesses disease control options
id: Emerging Themes and Approaches in Plant Virus Epidemiology

title: Investigating the Latency Period of Grapevine Red Blotch Virus in a Diseased Cabernet franc Vineyard Experiencing Secondary Spread
summary: This study estimates the latency period of Grapevine Red Blotch Virus (GRBV) in Cabernet franc vines, revealing three distinct patterns of symptom onset after PCR detection, with latency ranging from 4 to 12 months, and confirming secondary spread via Spissistilus festinus.
relationships: GRBV infection leads to red blotch disease symptoms after a latency period of 4-12 months
PCR detection of GRBV precedes symptom onset by 4-12 months in most cases
Spissistilus festinus is a vector for secondary spread of GRBV
Symptom onset patterns vary: simultaneous detection and symptoms, or symptoms delayed by 4-12 months after PCR positivity
id: Investigating the Latency Period of Grapevine Red Blotch Virus in a Diseased Cabernet franc Vineyard Experiencing Secondary Spread

title: A decade of grapevine red blotch disease epidemiology reveals zonal roguing as novel disease management
summary: This study analyzed the spatiotemporal spread of grapevine red blotch virus (GRBV) over a decade in a California vineyard, showing disease incidence increased from 3.9% to 36.4%. Key findings include rapid virus spread near transmission hotspots, influence of precipitation and temperature on epidemic parameters, role of asymptomatic infections in spatial aggregation, and effectiveness of zonal roguing for disease management.
relationships: Precipitation (3-4 years later) influences epidemic parameters
Air temperature (same or 1 year later) influences epidemic parameters
Asymptomatic infections contribute to spatial aggregation
Secondary spread occurs from diseased to neighboring vines
Virus influx occurs from background sources
Vector population peaks correlate with acquisition timing
Lower GRBV titer in early summer correlates with vector acquisition
Zonal roguing reduces disease spread
id: A decade of grapevine red blotch disease epidemiology reveals zonal roguing as novel disease management

title: Epidemics and Crop Yield
summary: This chapter reviews the complex relationship between plant disease epidemics and crop yield, emphasizing the economic importance of crop loss assessment, historical context, and the development of empirical models to understand how disease intensity affects yield.
relationships: disease intensity negatively correlates with crop yield
control methods may reduce disease severity but not necessarily increase yield
epidemic development influences yield loss
sampling precision affects accuracy of crop loss estimates
id: Epidemics and Crop Yield

title: Toward Cloud-Native, Machine Learning Base Detection of Crop Disease With Imaging Spectroscopy
summary: This paper presents a cloud-based architecture using spectroscopic imagery and machine learning for early detection of plant diseases, specifically grapevine leafroll-associated virus complex 3 (GLRaV-3), to reduce agricultural losses and improve decision-making for stakeholders.
relationships: Climate change increases virulence, range, and dispersal of plant pathogens
SI combined with ML enables accurate disease detection and risk mapping
Cloud infrastructure facilitates scalable ML deployment for disease detection
GLRaV-3 causes significant economic losses in grape industry
id: Toward Cloud-Native, Machine Learning Base Detection of Crop Disease With Imaging Spectroscopy

title: Compendium of Grape Diseases, Disorders, and Pests, Second Edition
summary: A comprehensive reference guide for identifying, managing, and preventing grape diseases, disorders, and pests, updated with advances in research and expanded content including new sections on fungicides and spray technology.
relationships: Environmental conditions interact with host to cause diseases
Arthropod pests cause symptoms mistaken for infectious diseases
Fungicides and spray technology are management techniques for diseases
id: Compendium of Grape Diseases, Disorders, and Pests, Second Edition

title: Spatial Aspects of Epidemics—I: Pathogen Dispersal and Disease Gradients
summary: This chapter discusses the spatial component of plant disease epidemics, focusing on pathogen dispersal from a single inoculum source and the resulting disease gradients, emphasizing that disease intensity decreases with distance due to short-distance spore movement.
relationships: Distance from inoculum source inversely correlates with disease intensity
Spore deposition decreases with increasing distance from source
Probability of infection is a function of distance between inoculum and host
Disease spread results from inoculum dispersal, with new infections occurring near existing ones
id: Spatial Aspects of Epidemics—I: Pathogen Dispersal and Disease Gradients

title: Previsual symptoms of Xylella fastidiosa infection revealed in spectral plant-trait alterations
summary: This study demonstrates that hyperspectral and thermal remote sensing can detect previsual symptoms of Xylella fastidiosa infection in plants by identifying alterations in plant traits such as chlorophyll content, fluorescence efficiency, and pigment indices before visible symptoms appear.
relationships: Xylella fastidiosa infection severity correlates with decreased chlorophyll a+b content
Increased disease severity is associated with altered flavonol levels
NPQI index changes with infection severity
Fluorescence quantum efficiency and solar-induced chlorophyll fluorescence are affected by infection
Hyperspectral indices (e.g., NDVI, EVI) show significant differences across disease severity levels
id: Previsual symptoms of Xylella fastidiosa infection revealed in spectral plant-trait alterations

title: Decision Making in the Practice of Plant Disease Management
summary: This chapter discusses evidence-based decision making in plant disease management, focusing on two approaches: sampling for disease intensity classification (acceptance sampling) and predictive modeling using host and environmental data for risk assessment and intervention decisions.
relationships: disease intensity influences decision for control action
sampling data classifies disease intensity relative to threshold
host and environmental data predict disease risk
risk exposure level determines justification for intervention
id: Decision Making in the Practice of Plant Disease Management

title: Opportunities and challenges in combining optical sensing and epidemiological modelling
summary: This paper reviews the integration of optical sensing technologies (multispectral, hyperspectral, thermal imaging, LiDAR) with epidemiological modeling to improve plant disease prediction and management. It highlights how sensing can enhance model parameterization and host mapping, while modeling can improve data interpretation and sensor deployment, addressing challenges in disease identification, data quality, and emerging diseases.
relationships: Optical sensing data correlates with disease incidence and severity through changes in reflectance and vegetation indices
Epidemiological models use sensing data to parameterize host distribution and disease progression
Sensing improves model accuracy by providing high-resolution spatial and temporal data
Modeling informs optimal sensor deployment and data interpretation for disease detection
id: Opportunities and challenges in combining optical sensing and epidemiological modelling

title: Distinct Red Blotch Disease Epidemiological Dynamics in Two Nearby Vineyards
summary: This study investigates the epidemiological dynamics of Grapevine Red Blotch Virus (GRBV) in two nearby vineyards, revealing distinct patterns of disease spread influenced by initial infection sources (infected planting material vs. vector transmission) and phylogenetic clade distribution.
relationships: GRBV clade 1 and clade 2 isolates cause red blotch disease with no known biological differences
Infected planting material (rootstock or scion) leads to primary infections and spatial aggregation of diseased vines
Spissistilus festinus transmits GRBV, facilitating secondary spread and displacement of clades
Vineyard age and cultivar influence disease incidence and spread dynamics
Spatial aggregation patterns indicate vector-mediated transmission vs. planting source origins
id: Distinct Red Blotch Disease Epidemiological Dynamics in Two Nearby Vineyards

title: Phenotyping grapevine red blotch virus and grapevine leafroll-associated viruses before and after symptom expression through machine-learning analysis of hyperspectral images
summary: This study uses hyperspectral imaging and machine learning (Random Forest and 3D-CNN) to detect and differentiate grapevine red blotch virus (GRBV) and grapevine leafroll-associated viruses (GLRaVs) in leaves before and after symptom expression, achieving up to 87% accuracy in binary classification and outperforming visual assessment by experts.
key_variables: viral infection status (GRBV, GLRaVs, co-infection, healthy)
symptom expression stage (pre-symptomatic at veraison, symptomatic at mid-ripening)
relationships: Hyperspectral reflectance in visible domain (510-710nm) correlates with viral infection status
Machine learning models (CNN and RF) can classify infection status from hyperspectral data with high accuracy
Symptomatic stage data reduces false negative rates in detection
Co-infection with GRBV and GLRaVs is more challenging to differentiate than single infections
Important wavelengths for detection are in green, orange, and red spectral regions
Hyperspectral imaging outperforms visual symptom assessment for early and accurate detection
id: Phenotyping grapevine red blotch virus and grapevine leafroll-associated viruses before and after symptom expression through machine-learning analysis of hyperspectral images

title: Impact of novel methods and research approaches in plant pathology: Are individual advances sufficient to meet the wider challenges of disease management?
summary: The paper reviews advances in plant pathology, emphasizing the need for integrated systems-level approaches to address multifaceted challenges in disease management, including diagnosis, host resistance, epidemiology, microbiome impacts, climate change effects, and artificial intelligence applications.
relationships: Host genetic diversity reduces pathogen aggressiveness and increases yield stability
Pesticide use leads to resistance development in pathogens and vectors
Microbiome composition influences disease complexes and plant health
Climate change affects pathogen adaptation, vector dynamics, and disease spread
Artificial intelligence aids in diagnosis, surveillance, and predictive modeling of diseases
id: Impact of novel methods and research approaches in plant pathology: Are individual advances sufficient to meet the wider challenges of disease management?

title: Temporal Analysis II: The Components of Disease
summary: This chapter focuses on modeling polycyclic disease epidemics at the individual infection process level, including latent period, infectious period, and daughter infection formation, to understand population dynamics, epidemic thresholds, initial development, and final disease levels.
relationships: Latent period, infectious period, and daughter infection formation influence epidemic progress curve shape
Initial disease incidence (y0) affects epidemic development threshold and initial increase
Biologically meaningful parameters predict initial disease increase
Final disease level is determined by epidemic development and management strategies
id: Temporal Analysis II: The Components of Disease

title: The Study of Plant Disease Epidemics
summary: This chapter introduces plant disease epidemiology, emphasizing that epidemics involve changes in disease intensity over time and space in host populations, with management focused on controlling pathogen population growth rather than individual infections.
relationships: Pathogen presence leads to disease intensity increase in host populations
Disease intensity correlates with yield reduction and control costs
Resistant cultivars, chemical control, biological control, and cultural methods reduce disease intensity
Time and spatial location influence disease intensity dynamics
Inoculum presence in an area enables disease outbreaks
id: The Study of Plant Disease Epidemics

title: Scalable Early Detection of Grapevine Viral Infection with Airborne Imaging Spectroscopy
summary: This study demonstrates that airborne imaging spectroscopy (AVIRIS-NG) can detect grapevine leafroll-associated virus 3 (GLRaV-3) infection in Cabernet Sauvignon grapevines both pre-symptomatically and post-symptomatically with high accuracy (87% for asymptomatic, 85% for combined asymptomatic and symptomatic vines), using non-visible wavelengths to sense physiological changes induced by the virus.
relationships: GLRaV-3 infection causes changes in plant physiology and foliar chemistry
Physiological changes alter spectroscopic signals in non-visible wavelengths
Spectral data enables differentiation between infected and non-infected vines
Infection precedes visible symptoms, allowing early detection
Machine learning models (random forest) correlate spectral features with infection status
id: Scalable Early Detection of Grapevine Viral Infection with Airborne Imaging Spectroscopy

title: Temporal Analysis III: Advanced Topics
summary: This chapter extends plant disease epidemic models by incorporating crop growth dynamics, continuous primary infections, vectored transmission by insects, and numerical methods for complex scenarios, with applications to virus epidemics and control strategies.
relationships: Crop growth affects host density and disease spread dynamics
Primary infections over time influence epidemic initiation and progression
Vector feeding activity transmits pathogens from infected to healthy plants
Host size changes impact disease dynamics in systemic infections
Harvesting and planting schedules alter disease carryover between seasons
Epidemic thresholds can be derived analytically for models with discrete crop events
Numerical methods are required for complex scenarios beyond analytical solutions
id: Temporal Analysis III: Advanced Topics

title: Spatial Aspects of Epidemics—III: Patterns of Plant Disease
summary: This chapter discusses the importance of spatial patterns in plant disease epidemiology, emphasizing that patterns are outcomes of dispersal processes and environmental heterogeneity. It highlights how spatial analysis helps infer underlying biological processes, such as pathogen dispersal and vector behavior, and addresses scale dependence in observation and analysis for disease management.
relationships: Spatial patterns are realizations of underlying dispersal processes of pathogens
Environmental heterogeneity affects spatial patterns of disease
Disease intensity estimates are influenced by spatial patterns at chosen scales
Vector behavior (e.g., thrips for TSWV) correlates with spatial patterns of virus spread
Scale of observation and analysis determines inferences about patterns and processes
id: Spatial Aspects of Epidemics—III: Patterns of Plant Disease

title: Grapevine red blotch virus detection in the vineyard: Leveraging machine learning with VIS/NIR hyperspectral images for asymptomatic and symptomatic vines
summary: This study demonstrates that hyperspectral imaging (510-900 nm) combined with machine learning can detect grapevine red blotch virus (GRBV) in both symptomatic and asymptomatic vines with over 74% accuracy, using spectral features selected via binning and feature selection methods, offering a non-destructive tool for vineyard scouting and disease management.
relationships: GRBV infection causes changes in hyperspectral reflectance in specific VIS/NIR bands
symptom expression (peak at harvest) correlates with higher detection accuracy (75.7%)
asymptomatic vines pre-veraison can be detected with high accuracy (74.2%) using fewer spectral bands
spectral binning and feature selection methods (e.g., Recursive Feature Elimination) improve model efficiency and reduce dataset size
hyperspectral imaging enables non-destructive detection of GRBV, facilitating roguing and disease management
id: Grapevine red blotch virus detection in the vineyard: Leveraging machine learning with VIS/NIR hyperspectral images for asymptomatic and symptomatic vines

title: Measuring Plant Diseases
summary: This chapter discusses the principles and methods for measuring plant disease intensity, emphasizing disease incidence and severity as key metrics for epidemic analysis.
relationships: Disease incidence is the proportion or number of diseased plants or plant units
Disease severity is the (relative or absolute) area of plant tissue affected by disease
Mean disease severity is the average severity of all assessed plants, including disease-free ones
Conditional severity is mean severity divided by the proportion of diseased plants
id: Measuring Plant Diseases

title: Grapevine Red Blotch Disease: A Threat to the Grape and Wine Industries
summary: Grapevine red blotch disease, caused by grapevine red blotch virus (GRBV), is a major threat to North American viticulture. The virus is transmitted by the treehopper Spissistilus festinus and causes physiological effects including inhibition of sugar translocation, poor fruit ripening, altered wine quality, and significant economic losses. Research has focused on GRBV biology, transmission, epidemiology, and management strategies.
relationships: GRBV infection inhibits hexose translocation from leaves to fruits
GRBV suppresses phenylpropanoid pathway transcription
GRBV reduces soluble solids and increases titratable acidity in fruit
GRBV decreases anthocyanin accumulation and phenolic extractability
Spissistilus festinus transmits GRBV between grapevines
GRBV infection leads to poor wine quality (altered aromas, color, mouthfeel)
Higher virus inoculum levels increase disease spread risk
Using GRBV-negative planting material reduces disease incidence
id: Grapevine Red Blotch Disease: A Threat to the Grape and Wine Industries

title: Epidemiology and Management of Plant Viruses Under a Changing Climate
summary: This editorial introduces a special issue on plant virus epidemiology, highlighting challenges such as climate change, globalization, and vector interactions, and summarizing key research on diagnostics, surveillance, modeling, ecology, evolution, and management.
relationships: Climate change influences virus transmission and prevalence
Insect vectors facilitate virus spread
Co-infections (e.g., polerovirus and potyvirus) affect disease outcomes
Agricultural practices may drive virus evolution
Modeling supports surveillance and predicts virus emergence under climate change
High-throughput sequencing improves virus detection and understanding of infection dynamics
id: Epidemiology and Management of Plant Viruses Under a Changing Climate

title: Estimating Plant Disease by Sampling
summary: This chapter discusses the importance of sampling for obtaining quantitative epidemiological data to link theory with practical problem-solving in plant disease management, covering sampling terminology, sample size calculation, and reliability considerations.
relationships: Sampling provides data to estimate population parameters like mean disease incidence
Sample size affects reliability and precision of disease estimates
Population variance influences required sample size for desired confidence intervals
Bias occurs when sample estimates consistently deviate from true population values
id: Estimating Plant Disease by Sampling

title: The Three-Cornered Alfalfa Hopper, Spissistilus festinus, Is a Vector of Grapevine Red Blotch Virus in Vineyards
summary: This study confirms that Spissistilus festinus (three-cornered alfalfa hopper) is a vector of grapevine red blotch virus (GRBV) in vineyard settings, with transmission efficiency highest when fewer insects feed on restricted leaf areas, and demonstrates acquisition and transmission in both California and New York vineyards.
relationships: S. festinus acquires GRBV from infected grapevines (acquisition rate ~45%)
S. festinus transmits GRBV to healthy grapevines (transmission rate 3-10% with restricted leaf feeding)
Higher transmission occurs with fewer insects feeding on restricted leaf areas vs. entire shoots
GRBV is circulative and non-propagative in S. festinus
Transmission efficiency varies by geographic region (California vs. New York)
id: The Three-Cornered Alfalfa Hopper, Spissistilus festinus, Is a Vector of Grapevine Red Blotch Virus in Vineyards
